text: I just wanted to start by saying that I'm really grateful to Robin and Lakshmi for this annual gathering.

I've seen so many people
that I've learned from over the years, some of whom
have become good friends.
Laura Morgan Roberts, Irene Padavic, Modupe Akinola, Ray Johnson,

people I have really learned from, and when we talk about what
are the spaces for learning,

for rethinking, for imagining, this gathering has been a
space for me over the years. So I'm incredibly grateful and honored
to be a part of this conversation today. The last two years of this pandemic

have been really grueling for a lot of us, and the kind of isolation
that it's created,

despite the hyperconnectivity
that we've had, that some of us have had, means that

we are in desperate need of
some time and space for healing. And so, the kind of conversations

that I've had yesterday with people, whether it was kind of in
the formal presentations or in the small kind of
exchanges at the tables

have really sort of opened
up that space for me, so I'm very grateful. We've gathered here to
discuss the master's tools,

which by now you've heard many times is a quote from Audre
Lorde's famous essay,

"The Master's Tools Will Never Dismantle The Master's House." To quote another well-known
feminist of color
and gender theorist, Sara Ahmed, "Each time Lorde's words reach me,

they teach me. Every time I encounter her
work, I feel a ripple of hope."
I too feel a ripple of hope while thinking through the questions that animated Audre Lorde's work and ours,

and I'm really excited to
be among a group of people who have carried this
line of inquiry forward.

Similar to Sara Ahmed, I
find myself among many others who acknowledge the
intellectual and activist legacy

that has touched the lives
of people here in the U.S. where Audre Lorde was from
but also internationally

in so many other locations
around the world. Through this book, "Audre
Lorde's Transnational Legacies,"

we can find a rich history of how people from different parts of
the world took her work,

her ideas, built on them, and used them for their local struggles
and incorporated them

into transnational solidarities. Often by doing so, they
also challenged and reframed

some of the foundational assumptions that had underlined
the specific geographic and historical context
in which Lorde lived.

In thinking through the
utility of the master's tools, it is worthwhile to also
think through the metaphor

of the master's house and we heard actually, you
know, in the previous panel, some really beautiful
reframings of that question.

The translation of the word
"house" in Arabic is "bayt,"
but "bayt" does not only refer to house in the sense of a physical structure,

but also to family and to home. So translated, the word
"bayt" evokes a feeling

of not simply that which
must be dismantled, but it also evokes a broader
notion of a dwelling,

an abode, a shelter, a domicile, a home, a place that one can make
one's own by existing in it,

a mode of inhabiting that
goes beyond structure. And so, I would like
to start my talk today

by offering the concept of dwelling as a starting point for our exchange and alongside it, I place
these words in Arabic,

"min bayt ala bayt," which
means "from house to house," because it refers to the
title of an ethno poem

by Shamail Besaki, who
was one of my students. Shamail's poem is based on
ethnographic interviews,

which combines social research
and art, in her case poetry, and it's a deep dive
into the many languages

of a historic area in
Dubai, which covers Arabic, Persian, Hindi, among others.

This image is from her poem, which is a visual representation
of all the multi-lingual

interviews that she had
conducted in different homes, showing the fluidity
and movement of people
and their identifications. By invoking that title, I gestured towards

an epistemological view
from a non-US location and a reminder of the
richness of the many languages

that are not a part of
our conversation today. For this talk, Robin and Lakshmi asked me

to share a method called Self Tracing that I have been sort
of experimenting with over the last five
years during my teaching

at New York University in Abu Dhabi. So, New York University
has sort of a global campus

in multiple locations. One of them is Shanghai, the
other main one is in Abu Dhabi, which is in the United Arab Emirates.

And I've come to think
of Self Tracing as a form of critical pedagogy,

and critical pedagogy has
a long history, of course. Paulo Freire argued that the
real purpose of education

is to make and remake
one's self in the world. Bell Hooks argued that
it is to pursue freedom.

Achille Mbembe argued
that it is to see oneself as a universal source of meaning.

Yet in today's internationally
diverse classrooms facilitated by technology,
we're now, unfortunately,

all too familiar with this Zoom room, which can gather students
from various locations

around the world, or actually
by academic institutions that are making a claim to the global,

and they sometimes produce classrooms in which no two students
are from the same country.

So, asking questions about
decolonizing education and the geopolitics of
knowledge production

are deeply tied to
questions of social justice, and they are now more urgent than ever.

So in my remaining time,
I'd like to do three things. First, I'd like to tell you about

what motivated the
development of Self Tracing. And then second, I'd like to describe it and share three examples
of student projects

that I think can illustrate
what I've been working on. And then finally, I'd like to reflect on the potential
applications of this method,

so how I think this can be
helpful for our conversation, as we think through this question

of the master's tools together. So by training, I must admit
I'm a social psychologist.

I have evolved over the
years to many other things, but primarily somebody who focuses
on gender and globalization, and I identify as a Haligi academic.
In other words, I'm from the Gulf, so I'm half Saudi Arabian, half Bahraini

and I now live in the UAE where I teach at New York University Abu Dhabi. I've experienced my location
primarily as a citizen,

but I have also experienced
it through the eyes of my two children, Abudi and Lulu,
who are categorized as temporary residents since I cannot pass my citizenship to them

and therefore, their legal
status is children of foreigners.

In teaching my classes
on gender and the Gulf, I bring both my academic expertise,

in this case, the Gulf, I've also studied in various educational institutions abroad, as
you can tell by my accent.

In each location, the
categories I occupied changed, depending on the context. For example, when I
moved to study in the US,

people referred to me
as a person of color. When in the UK, I was described
by others as Middle Eastern.

Interestingly, at branch
campuses of American universities in the Arab world, I
get this rather bizarre,
"Oh, but how are you so modern?" (audience chuckles)

So every time I was in a
new learning environment, I've had to engage in a sort
of sense-making exercise
to be able to process who I was in relation to the context that I was in,

and to succeed in educational institutions requires not just acquiring
skills or knowledge,

as we heard so beautifully
from our speakers this morning, as well as many of the
presentations from yesterday,

but also, it requires an ability to feel your way through
them, to not be numb,

but becoming numb is what many
of us do in order to survive.

So in my own experience, many
of the educational experiences that I had were simply in the head,

and there was very little
room to sort of process or even speak about the deeply
emotional work of learning.
So I wanted to bring to the classroom something that I felt was lacking, a sort of shift from did they get it,

to how to help students
make sense of their own learning journeys that are
actually specific to them.

So what is the Self Tracing method? Self Tracing really, I
think at its sort of core,

is about activating the body
as a source of knowledge, to address the thinking feeling binary
that can operate in a classroom and this basically entails two practices.

The first is situating the text and the second is learning
to read effectively.

So, situating the text
means invoking the body that wrote the academic text.

That means paying close attention to the things that undergird the choices that professors make when
they build a syllabus.
Who wrote the text? When? For what kind of audience?
In what language is it written? In what kind of publication? What debate was it a part of?

And so, the ability to
situate the text means students can potentially move away

from reifying academic
texts, concepts, or findings as necessarily knowledge
bearing to seeing them

as demystified products of human labor, something that may be
obvious to academics,

but not necessarily to
students in the room. They're produced for a purpose.

They're also a part of a
cultural and political economy that privileges some
locations over others.

The second part of the
embodied reading practice entails learning to read effectively and this does not mean,

"What did you understand from the text?" Or, "How do you critique it?" But rather, "How does it
feel when you read this text?
Are you angry? Are you indifferent?

Are you inspired?" Being in your body as you read the text allows you to tap into
articulating a standpoint,

not simply a critique from nowhere, but a view from a place that
does something for your life.

For example, for my class,
Women and Work in the Gulf, we read Lila Abu-Lughod's classic essay,

"Do Muslim Women Need Saving?" which later got published as a book. The post-colonial
anthropologist makes an argument

about the ways in which
mainstream US feminism constructs images of
oppressed Muslim women

that are then used to justify
foreign policy interventions, as in the case of Afghanistan.

While the book was written
about 10 years ago, the resonances are
hauntingly timely once again.

So in reading this text, one
student looks up wide-eyed and says she was so overwhelmed
when she read this essay

that she choked up. She finally found a text that
articulates in academic terms,

a kind of experience that
she's had her whole life, but she, and now I'm quoting, "doesn't have fancy words for."

A second student hesitantly describes how she finished reading
the essay with a hot face,

because she came into this
class with a firm belief that Muslim women are less free
and that it's their religion

that is the source of their oppression. She describes how sharing
this makes her feel ashamed

in the context of our class. A third student says she was
angered after reading this text

because the same argument
of cultural relativism is made by agents of feminism,

state feminism in her own country. She says her anger led her to
realize that this kind of lens

might help you if you were
already living in the West. But if you are living outside of the West,

you already know you are going
to have to save yourself. So these are simply three
examples of effective reactions
to one text, but in all of them, students have used their bodily reactions, choked up, hot face, bubbling anger,

to access knowledge that
is not simply in the head, but also embodied and relies
on their lived experience.

And so, I've asked my students to sort of collect
those moments over time,

to do it over the course of the semester, sort of systematically without
thinking too much about them

and often, they'll do this digitally, so for example, using voice
notes on their phones or cameras
and the digital part of this method is not just for convenience's sake, but actually it's sort of a way to escape

the hegemony of language because the language of
instruction at NYU Abu Dhabi is in English, which is a
second or even third language

for most of my students and language always presupposes
a certain kind of audience

with associated cultural references. So instead with this method,
students can capture material

in images and then narrate
them but as a second step and in fact, they're often free to write

in any language they want
and to think critically about the role of language in
their construction of self.
So I ask them to sort of do three things. Actually I ask them to do one thing, but in sort of three ways,
to reflect on the kind of identities and identifications that they have,
that they feel are salient for them at this particular moment in time. These are not stable.

As we heard, you know, earlier
from a number of talks, they're very context dependent,

but the first is to really
think about the intersection of sort of mainstream identity categories,

things that we've discussed a lot, especially on our first
day and we certainly heard from the panel this morning,
gender, race and class.

I would also add to that nationality because in that context,
that becomes quite relevant. In the second kind of group
of things that they reflect on

are identity categories
that are beyond the U.S., meaning the kind of things
that we have not touched on

really, you know, in our conference, except maybe for a little bit. So, Pushkala had this
fantastic presentation

about racial capitalism at
the planetary scale, right? So this is a sort of
different sort of framing,

but questions that are
specific to particular kinds of locations in which
things like tribe, sect, cast,

even religion and other kinds of things that emerge out of locations
in the global south.

But then the third is actually
not at all about categories. And in fact, it's about
experiences that demonstrate

the limitation of available categories. Sometimes we don't have words
for things that we experience,

but we know we felt them and so, making a little
bit of space for that is also really important.
And basically at the end of the semester, they submit an essay and a final project, which can be in any medium they choose:

film, photography, poetry, performance, art, or installation. And at the end, honestly, the
only prompt that I give them

is to listen with curiosity. So what did another person's
presentation evoke for me,

and what have I learned from it? So this is not about evaluating, you know, something as one would
say, a midterm or a paper.

To give you a feel for the method and what it's produced so far, I'd like to share three
quick examples that I think

would be most useful for
our conversation today. The first project is a video essay

in which the student Naijah Rose Simon from Pittsburgh, Virginia
produces a response
to the book that I mentioned earlier by anthropologist Lila Abu-Lughod, "Do Muslim Women Need Saving?"

Using a post-colonial feminist lens, Naijah unpacks how discourses
about oppressed Muslim women

in the Middle East are complicit
in obfuscating inequalities

among women in the U.S. - I was born and raised in
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania,

a mid-sized town with a big city attitude. Pittsburghers are proud
people, and for good reason.

We're a leader in education and medicine. We have a deep investment in the creative and performing arts and a
somewhat insane sports culture.

Still, when it came time
to look for colleges, I definitely didn't want to stay at home. I started looking for schools
as far away as possible,

hoping to challenge myself
by leaving my comfort zone. When I first got my
candidate weekend invite,
my mom was immediately worried. She berated me with questions. Would I have to cover my hair?

Did I know that women
weren't allowed to drive and that they had no legal protections?

These early conversations
were frustrating. I knew that my mom's fears were unfounded, but I didn't have the
vocabulary to explain to her
what was wrong with her thinking. This was my starting point.

These early conversations were draining, often leaving me confused
as to what the truth was.
How do women in the Arab world live?

Come August, I wasn't sure if
I had made the right decision, and I was afraid that I
had unknowingly signed up

for more than I could handle. But what neither I or my
mom realized at the time was that my move to the
UAE was quite possibly
the best choice I could have made. Almost like a sign, the city of Pittsburgh Gender Equity Commission published a study

about a month after I left. Researchers at the
University of Pittsburgh found that Pittsburgh was
the worst city in America

for Black people and especially Black women
and girls to live in, and compared to 89 other cities
of similar characteristics,

White people in Pittsburgh
are pretty much on par with White people in other places. Black people, however,
are doing much worse

than their counterparts
across the country. The Black residents
automatically, by moving, their life expectancy would go
up, their income would go up,

their educational opportunities
for their children would go up, as well as their employment.

My mom thought that I was
making a dangerous mistake by leaving, but the real
danger was in staying.

The irony of the situation
points to how pervasive these Western caricatures
of the Arab world are.
Saudi Arabia is heavily segregated, and women have few legal rights.

My mother was able to
perceive the East as a place with no protections for women while living in the worst
possible city in the nation

for women of her status. To look back on these conversations and understand the processes
underlying her beliefs

is a new thing for me. It's something I can do now because of what I've
learned this semester.

She was caught in a
framing of the Arab world that emphasized liberal Western feminism and asserted that there was a
right way for women to live,

a feminism that privileges the West and flattens and punishes the East. She clung to this feminism
as a way to bolster herself

in relation to less privileged Arab women, despite the fact that this
feminism didn't serve her

or people who looked like her. Not only have I gained
the ability to recognize the origins of false narratives
about the Arab world,

but I've gained a new understanding of my place within the Gulf. Understanding the connections
and tensions between citizens,

expats, migrant workers,
and the roles they each play within Gulf society has
helped me to understand

who I am as I move across space. I've discovered new identities
that may apply to me,

like a possible agent of cultural erasure or a quote "cosmopolitan employee." Spaces I can occupy
that I didn't even know

were available to me. I look back on my starting
point, wondering what it meant, if anything, to be a woman in the Gulf
and realize now that I know where to start to answer my own question.

- As you can see in her
Self Tracing project, Naijah did two things. So she first sort of examines
her original starting point,
which was in the US and describes how the domestic experience of race and gender for her, actually race,
class, and gender, is shaped by constructs about oppressed other women elsewhere.

But secondly, she comes to term with how her own intersectional
experience changes

after she leaves the US, such that not only are race,
gender and class operating,

but her nationality too. For example, when she
mentions this reference to a sort of cosmopolitan identity,

an identity that I didn't
know was available to me in the past, she reflects
on the new possibilities

that emerge when she
embraces the advantages of what some people call a strong passport

in an international setting, which comes also with other
things tied to symbolic capital
in labor markets in the global south. In the second project, Suman Ansari,
a student who grew up in Dubai also talks about her starting point.

But unlike Naijah in the first example, Suman has a lot of actual
lived experience in the Gulf.
However, she uses her Self Tracing project to revisit the starting point in ways
that she hadn't previously. Rather than using existing categories that she applies to herself,

Suman questions whether
the available categories are actually constraining for her.

- I always felt like
being a third culture kid was actually going to hold me back

from becoming, like, an empowered woman who could like, do
anything she wanted to do because not fitting in anywhere.
But I feel like after taking this class, it's been challenged so many times.

Growing up, there are like
certain instances that you feel like you realize, like it
hits you that you're different
and you're never going to be like someone who's from this place, which is hard

because when you go back home, that doesn't feel like home either. But obviously, you can never
say you're from the UAE

because you're not. So you always have to introduce
yourself as Pakistani,

but I can't even read
Urdu, I can't write Urdu but I can read and write in
Arabic, which is crazy too.

In a way, I feel like my
life has been like a journey of discovering.

I know it sounds so cliche, but it's like discovering
what exactly my identity is,

and I know it's not a
person who's from here because I'm not, but it's also not like a Pakistani
who was born in Pakistan.
It's somewhere in between. And it's made me realize that like,

all of us have very complex stories, and there's other people that I would see on the street that I might
have simplified their stories.

But like, even for example, a labor worker that's working
on the construction site, like across from our campus,

he's not just, you know, a
worker, he's also a father, he's a sibling, he's a son,

he's a resource and an
income for his family. And I think we try so hard to fit
into certain kind of labels, and it's so much more complex than that.

- So as you can see, Suman
unpacks her complex positionality as the daughter of Pakistani
parents who lives in Dubai.

She's Arab passing, yet
does not speak Urdu. Because the migration regime in the UAE

does not make it possible
for her to naturalize, she struggles to find
a label or a category

in her condition of
being a non-local local. However, in her project,

she interviews other people
who have faced challenges like her and starts to reclaim Urdu

as a language for herself,
and these kind of slow, almost methodical interactional
performances of identity,

like putting on a bangle as a way to come to terms with who she is. Iqrar, the word that she
uses for her project,

has the same meaning in
both Urdu and Arabic, "confession, acceptance."

She therefore moves away from the feeling of being a third culture kid
who is neither this nor that

towards a space of claiming
both cultures and more. Indeed, that complexity in identification

is something that extends
beyond her own experience to her perceptions of
other groups of people
in her social world. The last project that I'd like to share is a short ethnographic documentary,

found that while doing
her Self Tracing project, she had come in with some
very strong assumptions

about the women that
she wanted to document and that she was looking at this project

really primarily through
a sort of middle-class ethnographic gaze that could only see them

as oppressed domestic workers, as sort of other against which
the more privileged viewer

becomes a voyeur. That enabled her to broaden
the scope of her inquiry, so that she's not just simply documenting
the lives of domestic workers, but also of migrant mothers who work

and in doing so, she shifted
her project to engage in a sort of participatory art making form

in which the participants in the work actually became her partners
in the editorial decisions

about the film itself. This short excerpt features
one of them, Brenda,

who you can see calling
her son in the Philippines. - Hi, Brent.
(Brenda speaks Tagalog)
Mama loves you so much. Bye.

♪ Shining through the city
with a little funk and soul ♪ ♪ So I'ma light it up like
dynamite, whoa oh oh ♪
♪ Bring a friend, join the crowd ♪ ♪ Whoever want to come along ♪ ♪ Word up, talk the talk ♪
♪ Just move like we off the wall ♪ ♪ Day or night, the sky's alight ♪ ♪ So we dance to the break of dawn ♪

♪ Ladies and gentlemen,
I got the medicine ♪ ♪ So you should keep ya eyes on the ball ♪
(phone ringing)

- (chuckles) Just speak
English a little bit. Show your face.
Come on. Where is Aunty Benette and Aunty Blessing?
They could say hi. - They're here already. - Hi Dane, so this is Dane.

Dane, show your face. So that's my niece, the
daughter of my sister,
who's the teacher. - Hello. - Say hi, Dane. They are also students like you. - Hi, everyone.

- Hi.
- Hey. - (chuckles) And where is Rain?
- Rain! - So when he was, how old are you here?
Eight years old. My sister used to send me a photo

and keep the photo of
him and send it to me, so I will not forget how old is he

because I was not with him since. Actually I leave him
when he was 23 days old.

My mama works as an OSW in UAE. She is a super strong
single woman, I know,
and she is my main goal. I want to stop mama from working and live her life to the fullest,

and I can't wait to see her
doing something she really want.

I mean, there's a lot of message sometimes because he's not the person
who keeps talking like me.
He's just quiet. But in his mind, I mean,
I think he loves me. (laughs)

to a flattened out
uni-dimensional representation and while the film in other
sections does not shy away

it simultaneously interrogates
the us versus them that often plagues this kind of work

in both film and social research. In naming her project, Umalis
Si Maama, migrant mother,

which is a combination of two languages, Tagalog, the language of
the Filipino protagonist,

and Luganda, the language
of the Ugandan protagonist, Nandini reflects her desire
to move beyond narratives

of domestic work that
are produced in English through a Eurocentric Western lens.

Now, this is an example,
unlike the first two, of a project that was
actually not done in my class. It was done as an
independent research project
for her senior thesis, but she took the Self Tracing methodology and sort of applied it there.

So really, I just sort of to sum up here, wanted to say that in the three
examples that we just saw,

students sort of come to unpack
intersecting identifications

in order to produce insights that are based on their
effective and embodied reactions.
So in which women need saving, we see how categories like gender, race and class intersect with nationality,

which only becomes salient
in a non-US context. Iqrar shows how dominant binary categories

like citizen versus
immigrant can be reductive and constraining while
reflections on language

and embodiment can produce a new language for one's sense of belonging. Umalis Si Maama shows how
representations of migrant work

requires attention to power
at the structural level, but also at the discursive level

to move beyond colonial
tropes of representations of the global south, that
feed into extractive modes

of knowledge production. Now, it goes without saying that no matter how much trust
is built in a classroom,

ultimately it's a performative space. The power asymmetrically
rests with the professor

who also ultimately gets to grade them, not just on this assignment,
but on everything else

and students, when you ask
them, can you please reflect, they're going to reflect
and give you something

that sounds like a reflection. So, you know,
(audience laughs)
it is very, you know, clear to me that this is not an absolute sort of summation

of what the person is, or even necessarily an honest
reflection on things in life.

It's an attempt to kind of do
something for an assignment.

But in my description today, what I'm really not able
to kind of communicate is what palpably shifts in the room

when students actually
share their experiences with one another. And so, there are tears,
laughter, shame, rage
and often a sort of resignation that one is in the middle of a process

that is not yet complete. And so, what unravels is
far deeper than the text
that we've been reading all semester and students are sort of really learning

to sort of talk about how
their everyday interactions and conversations can actually play

into the social categories
that feel like sticky words

through knowledge that is
both embodied and effective. And so, what this means is that,

slowly, they start to
understand that the position in which one is both materially
and discursively located

simultaneously through body, time, space and historical power relations
gives one the ability

to see a specific part of that reality. And by doing so, the
classroom turns into a space

for situated knowledge production that enables students to deconstruct and sometimes reconstruct
deeply held assumptions

about their social world. And now, this really leaves
me to my very last point,
which is, so what do we do with this? Or are there any applications beyond that one particular classroom?

While I think that this
method and many others that attempt to do the same thing are actually really important
in addressing the thinking,

feeling binary that
operates in a classroom, I mean, even in a context like
the one that we're in now,

I show you an excerpt of the film and just even seeing
people's face expressions

means that as you
receive this information, different people are
processing this information in different ways in relation
to their own starting points,

in relation to what they know about or don't know about the locations
that I'm sharing with you.

But also, after a while,
these emotions bubble up. That's why Robin and Lakshmi are so clever

in that they designed this kind of space so that people end up
talking to each other around a small table.

Those smaller, slightly
more intimate conversations is what allows people to breathe.

Oftentimes, you go to these conferences where it's just one long
presentation and a Q&A where two people ask a question,

and you leave feeling like
you just wanted to, you know, say something that you couldn't. Well, actually, that's because
this thinking-feeling binary

is being imposed on us in
these academic contexts, and it's not normal.

Like, it, you know? So rather than clamping down on feelings that get in the way, how
about thinking of a way

to sort of organize an open air classroom? The second thing that I
wanted to say is that,

actually, you know, I
didn't call this a method until I had to put something
together for my tenure docket

because at the beginning, I
was doing it really almost, I want to say secretly, you know, because I wasn't really sure
that it would be accepted
or that maybe it was too much. But also frankly, because it takes a lot

to kind of be in a classroom environment where you're trying to make
space for what you don't know

and every educator has
their own starting point and even limitations to
how they were trained.

And so, this sort of thing
was just really an attempt to help me learn about
things I didn't know
about the people that are in my room and maintaining that sense of curiosity

rather than defaulting to,
I need to be the authority, ultimately I need to constantly signal

that I am the one that holds
the power over knowledge, it's not easy, it's
really not easy at all.

And I guess the third thing
that I wanted to say is that

I think this question
of critical pedagogy, which has been asked by
many different people in many different locations,
is one potential way

to engage in what some people have called decolonizing the
classroom or questions of,
